results.headline: A Paragon of Honor, With a Little Time Off for Love
results.summary_short: In remake of 2012 Tamil hit, Akshay Kumar stars as a captain on home leave in “Holiday.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Holiday

results.headline: A Legal Chess Game Leading to ‘I Do’
results.summary_short: The documentary “The Case Against 8” portrays the harrowing legal battle leading to the reversal of California’s ban on same-sex marriage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Case Against 8

results.headline: Right Guy Is Just One in a World of Choices
results.summary_short: The cautious yet funny rom-com “Obvious Child” stars Jenny Slate as a Brooklyn woman who faces an unexpected pregnancy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Obvious Child

results.headline: A Home Invader, Creepily Charismatic
results.summary_short: In Alex van Warmerdam’s malevolent adult fairy tale, “Borgman,” an enigmatic, beady-eyed drifter intrudes on the lives of a rich suburban family.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Borgman

results.headline: How to Meet Cute in France: Whimsical Stabbings, Genial Strokes
results.summary_short: In “2 Autumns, 3 Winters,” a stylistic homage to French New Wave cinema, three young adults come together by chance and stay together because of something more.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 Automnes, 3 Hivers

results.headline: Where Bigfoot Roamed
results.summary_short: “Willow Creek” is a work of restraint rarely seen from its writer and director, Bobcat Goldthwait.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Willow Creek

results.display_title: Walking the Camino: Six Ways to Santiago
results.headline: A Journey for the Soles and the Soul
results.summary_short: “Walking the Camino: Six Ways to Santiago” documents travelers who make the trek to the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walking the Camino: Six Ways to Santiago

results.headline: It Takes Some Heat to Create Movie Stars
results.summary_short: “Trust Me,” written and directed by Clark Gregg, stars Mr. Gregg as a scuffling, obsequious agent specializing in child actors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trust Me

results.headline: Killed in Action by Aliens, Over and Over Again
results.summary_short: In “Edge of Tomorrow,” Tom Cruise plays a military man caught in a time loop, destined to battle invading aliens day after day in a repeating bid to save Earth from Armageddon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Edge of Tomorrow

results.headline: A Passionate Symbol, Even Without the World Cup
results.summary_short: “This Is Not a Ball” is a soccer documentary that focuses primarily on the ball itself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This is Not a Ball

results.headline: A Horror Story Borrows From History
results.summary_short: In “The Sacrament,” written and directed by Ti West, two journalists accompany a man traveling to meet his sister, a recovering addict, at a compound in a foreign country.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sacrament

results.headline: Playing Ball in the Shadow of Warfare
results.summary_short: “The Only Real Game,” directed by Mirra Bank, traces the history of baseball in Manipur, a state in India, where it was introduced during World War II.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Only Real Game

results.headline: Young Love, Complicated by Cancer
results.summary_short: In “The Fault in Our Stars,” a film based on the young-adult novel, two teenagers with cancer fall in love and grasp the meaning of their lives earlier than usual.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fault in Our Stars

results.display_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon
results.headline: A Star Client List and a Magic Touch
results.summary_short: The comedian Mike Myers directs the documentary “Supermensch,” about the talent manager Shep Gordon.

results.headline: Bringing Blood to the Neighborhood
results.summary_short: The Hong Kong horror film “Rigor Mortis” puts an actor through an exorcism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rigor Mortis

results.headline: It’s 1985 All Over Again
results.summary_short: Michael Tully’s “Ping Pong Summer” centers on a teenager and his family’s seaside vacation in Ocean City, Md., three decades ago.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ping-Pong Summer

results.headline: Surviving a German Trading Floor, Ruefully
results.summary_short: Marc Bauder directs a German documentary in which a former stock trader divulges his experiences and observations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Master of the Universe

results.headline: Woman in an Endless Coma, Circled by Endless Debate
results.summary_short: The filmmaker Marco Bellocchio’s 2012 drama, “Dormant Beauty,” draws on a famous right-to-die case to perform a kind of CT scan on the Italian republic and some of its citizens.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bella Addormentata

results.headline: He’s Just Like Her Ex-Boyfriend, Down to the Tattoo
results.summary_short: In the thriller “The Moment,” Jennifer Jason Leigh is a war photographer consigned to a psychiatric hospital who meets a doppelgänger for her ex-boyfriend.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Moment

results.display_title: Small Small Thing - The Olivia Zinnah Story
results.headline: A Culture of Child Rape in Liberia
results.summary_short: Jessica Vale’s documentary “Small Small Thing: The Olivia Zinnah Story” offers an unflinching look at the culture of rape in Liberia.
